So I returned, and considered all the oppressions that are done under the sun: and behold the tears of <FI>such as were<Fi> oppressed, and they had no comforter; and on the side of their oppressors <FI>there was<Fi> power; but they had no comforter.<RF>side: Heb. hand<Rf>
Wherefore I praised the dead which are already dead more than the living which are yet alive.
Yea, better <FI>is he<Fi> than both they, which hath not yet been, who hath not seen the evil work that is done under the sun.<CM>

Again, I considered all travail, and every right work, that for this a man is envied of his neighbour. This <FI>is<Fi> also vanity and vexation of spirit.<RF>every…: Heb. all the rightness of work<Rf><RF>for this…: Heb. this is the envy of a man from his neighbour<Rf>
The fool foldeth his hands together, and eateth his own flesh.
Better <FI>is<Fi> an handful <FI>with<Fi> quietness, than both the hands full <FI>with<Fi> travail and vexation of spirit.<CM>
Then I returned, and I saw vanity under the sun.

There is one <FI>alone<Fi>, and <FI>there is<Fi> not a second; yea, he hath neither child nor brother: yet <FI>is there<Fi> no end of all his labour; neither is his eye satisfied with riches; neither <FI>saith he<Fi>, For whom do I labour, and bereave my soul of good? This <FI>is<Fi> also vanity, yea, it <FI>is<Fi> a sore travail.
Two <FI>are<Fi> better than one; because they have a good reward for their labour.
For if they fall, the one will lift up his fellow: but woe to him <FI>that is<Fi> alone when he falleth; for <FI>he hath<Fi> not another to help him up.
Again, if two lie together, then they have heat: but how can one be warm <FI>alone<Fi>?
And if one prevail against him, two shall withstand him; and a threefold cord is not quickly broken.<CM>
Better <FI>is<Fi> a poor and a wise child than an old and foolish king, who will no more be admonished.<RF>who…: Heb. who knoweth not to be admonished<Rf>
For out of prison he cometh to reign; whereas also <FI>he that is<Fi> born in his kingdom becometh poor.
I considered all the living which walk under the sun, with the second child that shall stand up in his stead.

<FI>There is<Fi> no end of all the people, <FI>even<Fi> of all that have been before them: they also that come after shall not rejoice in him. Surely this also <FI>is<Fi> vanity and vexation of spirit.<CM>
